Vibration testing of beams

 

 

Results:

The Experiment include the shaer deformation effect and the rotatory inertia effect,the latter caused by an angular acceleration of a bar element. The shear deformation effect is reflected in the second integral in the potential energy expression,and the rotatory intertia effect is represented by the second integral in the kinetic energy expression,When the cross-sectional dimensions are small compared with the length of the bar,both the shear and the rotatory intertia effects can be neglected.

Let us assume that this is the case and if the external load is zero,p(x,t)=0,can be combined into single equation,

∂2/∂[EI(x) ∂y(x,t)/∂x2]=-m(x)∂2y(x,t)/∂t2

Bending Vibration of Bars

We used the case of a bar in bending vibration to illustrate an eigenvalue problem. It was shown there that the problem reduces to finding the values of ω and Y(x)so that the equation

d2/dx2[EI(x) d2Y(x)/dx2]=ω2m(x)Y(x)

has a nontrivial solution over the domain 0 < x < L,where Y(x) satisfies four boundary conditions,two at each end.

Now the natural frequencies and the normal modes of the uniform clamped-free beam.The beam is uniform,so the diffrential eqaution to be statisfied over the length of the beam reduces to

d4Y(Y)/dx4- β4Y(x)=0,    β4=ω2m/EI

At the clamped end,x=0,we have the imposed boundary conditions

Y(0)=0,

dY(x)/dx|2=0

At the free end,because the bar is uniform,we have the boundary conditions,

d2Y(x)/dx2|x=L=0,

d3Y(x)/dx3|x=L=0,
